content:
You are not being asked to login to Thunderbird or a Thunderbird account, you are being asked to login to what appears to be a gmail account at imap.googlemail.com, i.e. gmail.

Do you have a domain registered with google?
creator: wsmwk

content: Thunderbird's addressbook is not a safe sender's list, but it does ensure emails from the individual are not automatically sent to spam. Your only true safe solution for the person is to create a filter.
creator: davidsk

content:
If you use POP and the server spam filters puts the email into the server Spam folder then you are not going to see email in a Pop mail account because pop accounts can only access and download emails that are in server Inbox. You will only see those emails if you logon to the webmail account and then locate email in Spam - mark it as not spam to put it into the server Inbox - then in Thunderbird use 'Get Messages' to download it. Please be aware that many servers auto empty Spam periodically.

Advise: logon to your webmail account via a browser and see if there is a 'safe sender' option - most server offer this, That would ensure emails from that sender stay in server Inbox. I would do this even if you use an imap account.

In Thunderbird, you can add the email address/contact to an address book then make sure the 'Junk Settings' for the account are set up correctly.

  • In Account Settings
  • Select 'Junk Settings' for the account.
  • Suggest you enable adaptive junk controls
  • select your address books to act as a whitelist - aka good email addresses.

DEstination & Retention

  • Select 'Move new junk messages to'

If POP:

  • select 'Junk folder on and select account'

If IMAP:

  • Select: 'Other' and choose the 'Spam on account name/email address'

Note: If you use 'Imap' and email is in Junk - if it has a flame icon that is grey then server put it in Spam. If email has a red flame icon then Thunderbird put it in Spam. The Adaptive junk controls in Thunderbird need to be trained, so it's important to teach it what is junk and also what is not junk.

More info on Junk Settings: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
If it says beta, then you downloaded a beta installer, not the release. FWIW, Beta 139 was offered starting Wednesday at 9:17 PM Eastern time.

Doese https://blog.thunderbird.net/2025/03/thunderbird-release-channel-update/ help?

I didn't download any installer, except version 136 release channel. That provided me with a stable version of 136, and then my installation was AUTOMATICALLY updated to version 138, but the beta version. I expected the release channel to only install stable versions, otherwise I would have stayed on the ESR channel. Did I misunderstand, or have I been unlucky?

content: I downloaded the release channel version as soon as I got the email, and installed the version provided (136, as 138 was not available at that point). I, too, cannot see that install, but that was definitely the version which worked. When my installation was automatically updated to version 138, I noticed it was a beta version. I downloaded the release channel version of 138 and installed it over the top of the beta version, but that didn't replace the beta version. I was hoping that someone would be able to explain what had happened, but it seems it must have been a glitch or bug on my machine. I have been advised to stay on the ESR version because the add-ons I use are not going to be updated quickly enough to guarantee they will work with the new versions of Thunderbird from the release channel. I'd just like to say thank you to everyone who has contributed, and, although I still don't know what happened, I'll accept I probably never will. On that basis, I will close this problem.
creator: kevin2

content:
If you logon to webmail account via a browser do you see those missing emails? If no, then server is not receiving them so Thunderbird cannot display them.

In which case it's possible the sender is sending to wrong email address or the servers spam filters do not like the email and they are blocking it, often the filters will inform the sender about failure to receive the email due to spam.

Maybe you have reached your server quota and that means until you delete some emails off server, the server cannot receive anything as it's full.

Do you have a Pop or Imap mail account in Thunderbird ? If POP Pop accounts can only access and download from server Inbox, so if server is scanning mail and putting it into the server Spam folder then it cannot be downloaded to a pop account.

You would only see it via webmail account in the Spam folder. Best action is to set up the email address as a 'safe sender' in webmail account regardless of whether you use a Pop or Imap account.

Is the problem account a POP gmail account ? If yes, then it's not possible to properly delete emails by putting them in the server Trash folder. So, gmail just removes the Inbox label and archives the email in the server 'All Mail' folder. If the quota starts to get used up gmail will be a pain and is well known for not allowing all email to get downloaded in one go for pop accounts. There is only one known fix. Logon to gmail webmail account and access the 'All Mail' folder. Look for all the email that do not have a label and delete them. Gmail expects people who use POP to download mail and delete off server, so gmail can be a pain at times for those using POP.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Please check your computer and Anti-Virus for a VPN that has been enabled. Some AV products have a habit of auto enabling a VPN after an update. Servers do not like VPN's, they think you are a hacker because your IP address is hidden.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
What Anti-Virus do you use? Do you allow AV to scan your profile folders and files because it could be scanning files that get opened so that thundrebird cannot use them.

General advise is to access AV and set up an exception to not scan any profile folder or it's contents. After all, you would not want it to do anything with any of those files as you would be likely to lose data.

What Addon extensions are installed whether enabled or not? You can find a full list here: In Thunderbird

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • scroll down to 'Add-ons' section
  • Either post an image or Copy and paste all the infor in that section.

If you restart Thunderbird in safe mode does it fetch emails?

  • Help > Troubleshoot Mode
  • click on 'Restart'
  • click on 'Continue in Troubleshoot Mode'

content:
ESET AntiVirus has been known to cause issues with downloading emails. https://support.eset.com/en/kb7728-unable-to-access-or-receive-emails-in-thunderbird-with-eset-product-installed

Temporarily Disable ESET SSL/TLS Filtering:

  • Open ESET's main program window.
  • Press the F5 key to access Advanced setup.
  • Click "Protections" and then expand "SSL/TLS".
  • Disable SSL/TLS filtering temporarily.
  • Re-enable it after Thunderbird is working properly and restart your computer.

Exclude Thunderbird from SSL Filtering:

  • Open ESET's main program window.
  • Go to "Advanced setup".
  • Expand "Web and Mail" and then "Web and E-mail Protections".
  • Click "Exceptions".
  • Add an exception for Thunderbird's executable file.
  • Click "OK".

content: Thunderbird not deleting spam message's
creator: gipsyking

content: to update Thunderbird
creator: gipsyking

content:
If you have an IMAP account then the 'Spam' folder is a server default folder. Imap folders synchronise with server and can only display whatever is on the server. If server puts mail in Spam then you will see new mail in Spam when you next start Thunderbird. If you have Thunderbird account settings for 'Junk Settings' to put junk into the server spam folder then you may hav some additional mail put in Spam.

Many servers auto empty their 'Spam' folders periodically - some after a week others at the end of the month. The time varies depending upon the server.

In Thunderbird, you can right click on 'Spam' folder and select 'Empty Junk' Then right click on 'Spam' folder and select 'Compact' to clear all marked as deleted old traces of data.


In Account Settings - You can also set up the account 'Junk Settings' to auto delete junk older than X days.

I'm not entirely certain what your issue is all about. Everyone get's tons of spam/junk mail. Some is usualy removed by the server, the rest depends upon your settings and what you deem as junk/spam.

Are you just complaining that you get spam emails and they are being put into the Junk/spam folder ? OR are you complaining about what you call junk is not going to junk/spam folder - it's in the Inbox.

Maybe it would help if you posted some information to understand your set up otherwise I'm guessing. What OS are you using? What version of Thunderbird are you using? Is this an IMAP or POP account ? Post an image showing the Account Settings 'Junk Settings' window for the problem account. What server do you use ? eg: gmail, yahoo, comcast, BT, Telstra etc

Have you properly set up and trained the Thunderbird Junk adaptive filter ? Have you been trying to create your own Message Filters to deal with spam - not really advised because the adaptive filter will do the same job and it get's very complicated covering all the variations. Bit of a time wasting excercise in most cases.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: complaining about what I call junk is not going to junk/spam folder - it's in the Inbox. It used to send emails that I thought it was junk strait into the Junk folder and one time when Thunderbird was updated it stopped doing it in spite of, I trained to do it again. At time I open Thunderbird I have 30-40 junk mail I have to deal with.
creator: gipsyking

content:
Hai un backup recente? Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)

content:
Imap accounts will always check server because they can only display whatever is on server. If server has already blocked you then consider yourself fortunate because if they had deleted emails but still allowed access then you would have lost all your emails when imap acount sycnhronised with an empty server.

You need to rescue all your emails - get copies put into 'Local Folders' and then remove the old account. If only a few folders you may prefer to do it manually, but if you have quite a lot then try the addon extension - all details below. There is another option to do all manually via profile folders after exiting Thunderbird - but I'll only provide that if requested.

In 'Local Folders' account: create some new folders to receive copies of emails.

In former uni account:

  • Select a small batch of emails to highlight
  • Right click on highlighted emails and select 'Copy to' and choose suitably named folder in 'Local Folders' account.

Please note - I said use 'Copy to' because if something goes wrong then you will not lose emails and you can repeat. Check you have good copies by randomly selecting a few to check you can read them.

Repeat until you have good copies of all emails in 'Local Folders'.

Alternative which may be useful if you really have a lot of folders and emails. Use addon extension called 'ImportExportTools NG'

  • https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-us/thunderbird/addon/importexporttools-ng/

How to install addon:

  • https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/installing-addon-thunderbird

After installing: Right click on 'Local Folders' account and select: 

'ImportExportTools NG' > 'Import mbox files' > 'all mbox files from directory with sbd structure'

Then you need to select the profile location, select the ImapMail folder and select the name of the former uni mail account folder and click on 'Select 'Folder'. This should then get copies of all folders including any subfolders into 'Local Folders' account,

Then you can remove the former uni account via : In 'Account Settings' Select name of uni account If using version 128* or earlier: click on 'Account Actions' and select 'Remove Account' Else you can click on red 'Delete' button located top right.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
If the content really is available locally, offline, you can do File > Offline > Work Offline. When it asks to download messages, pick "Later".

If the messages are not available locally you will see "Go Online to View This Message". Otherwise, you should now be able to copy messages fro the account.

content:
That is probably your Anti-Virus being a pain.

Usually you just click on the Add Exception option and all should be ok. But there are occasions when an Anti-Virus gets updated and it's logs are not properly updated so it thinks nothing is secure and wants to create exceptions.

What Anti-Virus product are you using?
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Have you set up to put emails in the Trash ?

If IMAP: Check you have subscribed to the server Trash folder.

In Account Settings

  • Select 'Server Settings' for the account
  • When I delete a message:
  • Select 'Move it to this folder'
  • Select the server 'Trash folder for the account'

Please note: There is a shortcut delete method which by-passes the Trash and there is no 'Undo' for this action. 'Shift' + 'Del' keys

If you use a gmail server and imap account then it's a useful method when you have two copies of email in different folders and you only want to delete one of them - basically if you by-pass the trash then gmail reads this as a remove label only.

content:
There is a specific forum for asking questions about 'Thunderbird Mobile'. This forum is for Thunderbird desktop/laptop users.

However..... That message is from a server - not Thunderbird. This may be the SMTP settings for the mail account. You have been blocked by Abusix Mail Intelligence which is probably being used as a server spam filter.

I looked at the website mentioned in the link they sent to you and entered the IP address. https://app.abusix.com/lookup/results?q=37.96.120.33

I also checked with spamhaus https://check.spamhaus.org/results/?query=37.96.120.33

I checked with mxtoolbox https://mxtoolbox.com/SuperTool.aspx?action=blacklist%3a37.96.120.33&run=toolpage


I find spamhaus to be reasonably helpful - I clicked on the more info and it says: 37.96.0.0/16 is listed on the Policy Block List (PBL) Outbound Email policy of The Spamhaus Project for this IP range

This IP address range has been identified by Spamhaus as not meeting our policy for IP addresses permitted to deliver unauthenticated 'direct-to-mx' email to PBL users.

Important: If you are using any normal email software (such as Outlook, Entourage, Thunderbird, Apple Mail, etc.) and you are being blocked by this Spamhaus PBL listing when you try to send email, the reason is simply that you need to turn on "SMTP Authentication" in your email program settings.

So you need to check your account SMTP settings because it sounds like you have not set up correct Authentication Method.

If unsure post image of SMTP settings.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Method 1:

In the following link: https://github.com/thunderbird/thunderbird-notes/blob/master/release/138.0.yml you can find the following text:

note: New mail alert now includes message disposition buttons tag: new bugs: [410338]

Therefore, it is bug 410338: Improve the alert notification for new mail to enable mark as read, junk, delete, etc. https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=410338

- - -

Method 2:

Although the release notes of 138.0 does not mention the bug: https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/138.0/releasenotes/ the release notes of 138.0beta does mention the bug: https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/138.0beta/releasenotes/ And in the release notes, there is a link to bug 410338.

content: On the account pane, look for a button 'Manage Identities' There, you can create multiple identities, each with different signatures. Be sure to use the same email address information. Then, when composing a message or a response, you can click the 'from' dropdown menu to select the desired identity and the desired sig will immediately appear.
